docs.lead_paragraph: A doctor who performs abortions here has been picketed while attending church on Sunday. Roman Catholics who work for Planned Parenthood have been threatened with excommunication. And the University of Nebraska Medical Center has been the target of angry protests over research on fetal tissue in the study of Alzheimer's and AIDS. Anti-abortion groups in Nebraska work with a passion that critics say verges on intimidation. But in this conservative, church-oriented state, there has been little political risk for those who denounce abortion with vehemence, such as the state attorney general, Don Stenberg, who condemned certain types of abortion as ''infanticide.''

headline.main: Abortion Foes In Nebraska Take Spotlight

docs.abstract: US Supreme Court will review Nebraska law that bans late-term or partial-birth abortion; even though similar laws in other states are winding their way through courts, Nebraska case has reached Supreme Court, in part, because state officials have aggressively sought legal challenge; state deputy attorney general Steve Grasz says Nebraska is first state to petition for Supreme Court review 1998 federal appellate ruling that found law to be so broad as to be unconstitutional; more than 20 states have enacted such bans, most have which have been struck down in federal courts as unconstitutional (M)
docs.snippet: A doctor who performs abortions here has been picketed while attending church on Sunday. Roman Catholics who work for Planned Parenthood have been threatened with excommunication. And the University of Nebraska Medical Center has been the target of...

docs.lead_paragraph: As Liana Gedz was wheeled into an operating room at Beth Israel Hospital in September, she had every reason to trust Dr. Allan Zarkin in delivering her first child. He had coached her through seven months of prenatal care, and the two had developed a friendship that one lawyer described as ''more than a doctor-patient relationship.'' It was the kind of bond that led Dr. Gedz, a dentist, to invite Dr. Zarkin, 61, to spend summer nights with her and her husband at their country home in East Northport, on Long Island.

headline.main: Doctor Carved His Initials Into Patient, Lawsuit Says

docs.abstract: Liana Gedz sues her obstetrician, Dr Allan Zarkin, accusing him of carving his initials into her abdomen during Caesarian delivery at Beth Israel Hospital in New York City on Sept 8; his lawyer says Zarkin suffers from brain disease; criminal investigation is under way; Beth Israel, which is also named in suit, has suspended Zarkin, and he has resigned from hospital (M)
